One of the classics, and seeing recent Zombie title releases solidifies even more how Left 4 Dead has maintained the gold standard for co-op zombie gameplay for all these years.

An original co-op zombie game. Fight the zombies or be a zombie. This is the first game that really makes you rely on teammates for assistance. Most players have moved on to L4D2, which certainly adds a lot of variety to the game, but L4D2 still feels incomplete and lacking in many ways. See my L4D2 review for more details. If you're trying to decide between L4D and L4D2, go with L4D.

*Update: although I believe L4D1 is better than L4D2. At this point in time L4D1 is pretty much dead. Most servers are empty. Versus is almost always empty. If you can find players for L4D versus most of them brazingly cheat, act like aѕѕhоles, grief and/or crash the server via ddos or an exploit when the game doesn't go in their favor. I personally contacted Valve two times about patching vulnerbilities in their vanilla servers to prevent ddos. I believe the exploit that can cause a server to crash can also be patched. Valve has ignored my pleas. By the looks of it Valve has abondoned all support for this game.

Great 4-player co-op zombie killing action.  Each run-through will never be the same thanks to the AI director, which often keeps things interesting, randomly spawning special infected, and tanks.  This keeps the game constantly challenging, and forces players to adapt to quickly changing situations, or die trying.  You have 2 tiers of weapons in your arsenal.  First tier gives you the Uzi and a pump action shotgun and the second tier gives you a more powerful M4 Assault rifle, auto-shotgun (Benelli I think makes it), and a semi-automatic sniper rifle.  You also get a choice of holding a pipe bomb or molotov as a throwable item, which can make the difference between saving the team from slaughter or get beaten down by a charging mob of zombies.

The Steam workshop also offers endless amounts of additional content, including skins for weapons/items, as well as custom campaigns.

Left 4 Dead (L4D) is a co-operative first person shooter, where the objective is to get your team of 4 survivors through a gauntlet of zombies and out of harms way. As a cooperative game - you are only as strong as your teammates. Teammates help against special zombies, some of which leave you helpless until teammates can save you. They can also share resources like pain pills, and heal you using their health pack. 

Although it offers a singleplayer experience, L4D is best played with at least one friend. Online multiplayer can be a bit hit-and-miss, due to players that will either disregard their teammates, or even join a game just to shoot everyone and leave. I recommend playing with friends you know, or befriending the good players that you meet online for future games.

There are also versus and survival modes which switch up the gameplay and allow you to play as some of the special infected (zombie) characters. In my opinion, Versus maps take too long - you have to play each level twice, once for each team, dragging a 40 minute campaign into an hour and a half. I don't think I've ever seen a Versus mode game through to the end.

On the other hand, Survival modes are great for quick and dirty (10 minute) games. If you're looking for a LAN party game where people take turns, this can be a good mode for that.

The other thing worth mentioning is the AI 'Director', a system which dynamically adjusts the gameplay based on how it thinks you are doing. If you get stuck against a horde of zombies and lose heaps of health, it may add more health packs or pills to the level. If you cakewalk through half a level with minimal damage, it might throw a large horde with a tank at you. This means that every game can be completely different depending on how things play out.

Overall, I do recommend Left 4 Dead. The price is great, you can get a 4-pack of copies for your friends, it plays great at small LAN parties, and doesn't require the highest top-end PC specs either. A great game to have in your Steam Library

I love Left 4 Dead. The atmosphere, the visuals, the pacing, the humor, the maps.

Valve reinvented co-operative gameplay with this title. Sure, there have been multiplayer games that let you mash bad guys as a group, but never done as thoroughly as L4D does it. Your team's survival depends on teamwork. And yet, it's never complicated. L4D rewards you for behaving exactly as you should behave if there really was a zombie apocalypse. Stay together as a group, watch each other's back. Share resources.

The Versus mode exemplifies these themes too, in that the infected team works best if the individuals cooperate and coordinate. 

All of this adds up to an awesome "beer & pretzels" alternative to your usual hardcore fare.

L4D2 one-ups L4D in many ways, but the atmosphere of the original is much darker. When Valve adapts all L4D maps for L4D2, there will be little reason left to buy this game... but still. It's on sale all the time. Enjoy a little piece of history.

BBBBBRRRRRAAAAAIIINNNSSSS..ahem..sorry,lost myself for a sec there. Anyway, this is the classic zombie shooter. The goal is simple: get from one point to the other, over various maps, and shoot undead people on your way there. Cool huh? HELL YEAH IT IS! Even tho the concept is simple, the game is really awesome. Either try to survive on your own, or invite up to 3 friends to kill alongside you! You can also play as one of 4 special infected and fight against 4 survivors! It also never gets old, as there's always new DLC coming out. So..yeah..BBBRRRAAAIIINNNSSSS >:D
This game is still fun to play! This is what started my Zombie enjoyment (Smart zombie movies, that is... is that an oxymoron?) Get it!

The zombie game that all future zombie games will no doubt strive to emulate in one way or another, Left 4 Dead throws you and three other players against the zombie hordes and their devious advanced mutations, who are also playable in multiplayer. Use team work to navigate the perilous streets of an infected city while fighting ravenous zombies and looking over your shoulder for more terrifying threats you often cannot see until it's too late.

Now there has been an update to L4D2 where you can play with the original characters on the original campagin while adding all the new things that came with L4D2. The melee system, the enhanced graphics, more weapons and more baddies. With this update L4D2 has essentially made L4D obsolete now that everyones favorite characters have moved up to the new game. If you are looking at purchasing this game I would recommend you just buy L4D2 now.

I remember when I first heard of this game, it was pretty hyped up. Played it, the first time, on my buddy's Xbox360, thought it was really cool! The gameplay mechanics seemed innovative and realistic, to a certain extent. Made you feel like you really were in the midst of a zombie apocalypse! Voice acting/dialog was entertaining and randomized, making replayability apparent. Jumping into online Versus mode was tough at first, many people who were veterans of the game were really hard-assed and mouthy at times. Unfortunately, due to the creation of countless exploit programs, and the game's failed glitch-circumvention, the game is at the point (echoed by many) of being "broken", as the community has been tainted.
I suggest playing single-player, or playing Versus between 8 friends (4 on 4). Otherwise, be prepared to see the worst the internet has to offer...
7/10

Left 4 Dead is a great co-op FPS in a surprisingly sparse field of co-op games.  It requires teamwork, bullets, and more bullets.  A great addition to a LAN or any game you play with friends.  Apparently it has solid multiplayer also, but I have never tried it.  I would pay $5 for the game just for co-op but keep in mind that Left 4 Dead 2 is this game's superior in every way.

i dont know why people gets so hyper about this game....but dont get me wrong, it still a very good game...very enjoyable too..great graphic/sound...sometimes i wished there are levels to compete in a normal way like onto the next levels automatically ...)

If you love zombie apocolypse movies, then jump into this game to star as one of four survivors in several zombie "movies." The boss zombies are reminiscent of "Resident Evil," and the regular zombies remind me of "28 Days Later" with the way they sprint at your tasty brains. Now with six campaigns (or "movies") to choose from, Left 4 Dead provides endless hours of zombie genocide; each time you play a campaign it's a little different, since details in the levels are randomized and the AI director adapts to your play style. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED to any fan of zombies, especially those that're first-person shooter fans as well. WARNING: This game will have you excited, on the edge of your seat, and might even scare you the first couple times. (Did you just pee a little?)
